title: Attempt to protect England’s rare chalk streams in planning bill rejected by Labour MPs
snippets:
Cross-party amendment to protect threatened chalk streams from government push to rip up environmental red tape fails

A cross-party attempt to protect England’s rare and threatened chalk streams in the government’s planning bill was rejected by Labour on Wednesday.

The attempt to give that the globally rare ecosystems the strongest protections as irreplaceable habitats failed after all the Labour MPs on the parliamentary committee examining the draft law rejected an amendment containing the extra provision.

Continue reading...
titles: Attempt to protect England’s rare chalk streams in planning bill rejected by Labour MPs
summary: A cross-party amendment aimed at safeguarding England's rare chalk streams by incorporating strong protections into the government's planning bill was rejected after Labour MPs on the parliamentary committee voted against it. This decision came amidst efforts to protect these globally rare ecosystems from the impacts of environmental deregulation. The amendment's failure means these habitats remain without the proposed highest level of protection.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides a good level of awareness about the importance of protecting rare ecosystems and the political challenges involved. It provides useful context about the planning bill and the amendment, contributing to the reader's understanding of environmental policy. However, it doesn't report on any successful solutions or progress.

title: AMD Stock Jumps as Chip Designer Announces New $6B Buyback Plan
snippets:
KEY TAKEAWAYS

  • Advanced Micro Devices shares jumped Wednesday, as the chip designer said its board approved a new $6 billion share buyback plan.
  • The move will boost AMD's buyback program to $10 billion, the company said.
  • The gains also come a day after AMD and rival Nvidia announced partnerships with Saudi Arabian AI startup Humain.


Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) shares jumped Wednesday, as the chip designer said its board approved a fresh $6 billion share repurchase plan, boosting its buyback program to $10 billion.

“Our expanded share repurchase program reflects the Board’s confidence in AMD’s strategic direction, growth prospects, and ability to consistently generate strong free cash flow,” AMD CEO Lisa Su said. 

The stock was up over 5% in recent trading, extending Tuesday's gains after the company announced a partnership with Saudi Arabian AI startup Humain.

AMD and rival Nvidia (NVDA) on Tuesday said they would supply semiconductors to Saudi Arabian AI startup Humain, as part of initiatives announced as President Donald Trump kicked off a four-day trip to the Middle East. Shares of Nvidia were also higher Wednesday, as several AI stocks gained amid expectations the partnerships could lead to more deals.

As part of AMD's partnership with Humain, the companies said they plan to invest up to $10 billion over the next five years to build out AI computing centers "stretching from the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia to the United States."

With this week's gains, AMD shares are close to recovering their year-to-date losses, but they've still lost roughly one-quarter of their value over the past 12 months.
titles: AMD Stock Jumps as Chip Designer Announces New $6B Buyback Plan
summary: On May 8, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) announced a new $6 billion share buyback plan, increasing the total buyback program to $10 billion. This decision reflects the board's confidence in AMD's growth and ability to generate strong free cash flow. Additionally, AMD and Nvidia have partnered with Saudi Arabian AI startup Humain, planning to invest up to $10 billion in AI computing centers over the next five years. This partnership, announced during President Trump's trip to the Middle East, has contributed to a rise in AMD's stock, which increased over 5% recently, helping to offset its y
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides useful information about AMD's business strategy and future plans. It also provides context about the company's partnership with Nvidia and Humain, which could influence investment decisions. However, it does not clearly highlight solutions or empowering knowledge, hence the score is not higher.

title: Gone in a Saccade: Why You Can’t See Lightning-Fast Motion
snippets: Our eyes perform lightning-fast movements called saccades multiple times per second, yet we never perceive the resulting motion blur. A new study reveals that this “invisibility” happens because the speed of our saccades sets a natural speed limit for what we can see. If an object moves faster than our eyes typically do during a [...]
titles: Gone in a Saccade: Why You Can’t See Lightning-Fast Motion
summary: A recent study has found that the human eye does not perceive motion blur during rapid movements known as saccades due to a natural speed limit set by the velocity of these eye movements. Objects moving faster than this speed are essentially invisible to us, explaining why we can't see extremely fast motion.
constructiveness_reason: This story provides useful insights into the workings of the human eye and why we can't perceive extremely fast motion. However, it doesn't necessarily report on solutions or improvements, nor does it give actionable insights for the reader.

title: “Zangenite” – Scientists Discover Never-Before-Seen Hollow Crystal

Crystals, whether found in sugar, table salt, snowflakes, or diamonds, do not always grow in a simple or predictable manner. Researchers at New York University have documented the transformation from a amorphous blob to an organized structure in [...]
titles: “Zangenite” – Scientists Discover Never-Before-Seen Hollow Crystal
summary: Scientists at New York University have discovered a new type of crystal named "Zangenite," characterized by its unique hollow structure. This discovery challenges the traditional understanding of crystal formation, showing that crystals can evolve from an amorphous state to a highly organized structure in ways not previously documented. The crystal is named in honor of the NYU graduate student who discovered it.
constructiveness_reason: The discovery of a new type of crystal contributes to the reader's understanding of crystal formation and challenges traditional understanding, providing deeper knowledge. However, it doesn't offer actionable insights or report on solutions to problems.

title: Chemists discover 'anti-spice' that could make chilli peppers less hot
snippets: An analysis of compounds in chilli peppers has revealed chemicals that seem to negate their heat-giving capsaicinoids. This explains why the Scoville scale for measuring spicyness isn't always accurate, and could eventually lead to the development of an "anti-spice" condiment
titles: Chemists discover 'anti-spice' that could make chilli peppers less hot
summary: Researchers have discovered compounds in chili peppers that counteract the heat-producing capsaicinoids, challenging the accuracy of the Scoville scale used to measure spiciness. This finding may pave the way for creating an "anti-spice" condiment, offering a new approach to managing the heat in spicy foods.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it provides a deeper understanding of the chemical compounds in chili peppers and their effects on our perception of spiciness. It also reports on an innovative solution for managing the heat in spicy foods, which could be useful for people who enjoy the taste of spicy foods but cannot tolerate the heat.

title: Heat and pollution events are deadly, especially in the Global South
snippets: Small particulate matter (PM2.5) in air pollution raises the risks of respiratory problems, cardiovascular disease, and even cognitive decline. Heat waves, which are occurring more often with climate change, can cause heatstroke and exacerbate conditions such as asthma and diabetes. When heat and pollution coincide, they can create a deadly combination.
titles: Heat and pollution events are deadly, especially in the Global South
summary: Exposure to small particulate matter (PM2.5) in air pollution is linked to increased risks of respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, as well as cognitive decline. Concurrently, more frequent heat waves due to climate change can lead to heatstroke and worsen conditions like asthma and diabetes. The combination of high pollution levels and extreme heat poses a significant health risk, amplifying the potential for deadly outcomes.
constructiveness_reason: This story is constructive as it raises awareness about the combined health risks of air pollution and heat waves, particularly in the Global South. It provides useful insights into the impacts of these environmental factors on various health conditions. However, it does not offer any solutions or progress in mitigating these risks, hence the score is not at the highest end.
